results.title: Mesas and gibber plains
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Arid Landforms”.
Gives examples of some Australian landforms resulting from weathering and erosion in arid regions, and discusses the formation of mesas and gibber plains. Animated diagrams illustrate formations. The importance of water erosion in arid regions is stressed.

results.title: Merseyside
results.brief_description: A survey of the Mersey River, one of the main arterials of Britain’s commerce from its soucre in the Derbyshire hills to its estuary below the port of Liverppol. As the river enters the sea, it is lined with docks, shipyards, and warehouses, which serve the continuous traffic on the Mersey River.

results.title: Meow meow
results.creator_credit: Red Grooms, Yvonne Anderson, Dominic Falcone, Ruckus Films and Yellow Ball Workshop
results.brief_description: A man and his pet lion. The lion overthrows a kidnapper and becomes a celebrity of New York City, type of city. he stars in a musical, is eventually kidnapped himself, is saved by a black bartender and eats the kidnappers. Totally wild, over the top, visually very colourful and fun animation.

results.title: Men who come back
results.brief_description: Deals with the safety precautions found necessary in most Ohio industries, such as a clean well-arranged shop, safety guards on machines, correct materials, handling techniques, the use of safety goggles and competent first aid treatment.

results.title: Men of the footplate
results.brief_description: Presents the work of ayoung man wishing to join the railway. Harry begins working at British Railway as a cleaner. He learns the names and functions of the steam locomotion parts he cleans. His eagerness leads him to progress to the role of fireman, hoping to eventually become a driver. Commentary by Frank Phillips.

results.title: Men like me
results.brief_description: “Men like me” is a collaboration between the filmmaker and Dale Michaels and was made in 1994 when female to male transgender was relatively unfamiliar to the broader community and rarely discussed. Informative and sensitively presented the film uses interviews, vox pops, archival footage and stills, combined with computer animated images and narration by Susan Long and Dale Michaels.

results.title: Memory of Christmas: from 'Act One' by Moss Hart
results.brief_description: A series of dramatic photographs illustrates playwright Moss Hart’s grievously impoverished childhood. The text, adapted from Hart’s autobiography “Act one” describes two Christmases a generation apart illustrating the gap that existed between himself and his father and how that gap was finally bridged.

results.title: Memento
results.creator_credit: Stefan Sharff and Centre for Mass Communication of Columbia University Press
results.brief_description: A fresh approach in the field of automobile safety, Memento uses picture and sound contrapuntally. Photographed in an automobile “graveyard”, the film presents a picture study of cars irreparably smashed in accidents, while the sound track reconstructs the voices of the participants of three particular accidents.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stefan Sharff and Centre for Mass Communication of Columbia University Press

results.title: Melodie En Sous-Sol = the Big Snatch (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
An ex-con sets up one last job and enlists the help of a younger crook to rob the Casino at Cannes. Everything goes according to plan, right up to the last minute until … A very standard caper film which gives one more opportunity to the trio Verneuil-Gabin-Audiard to send up the gangster genre with razor-sharp one-liners. Like his illustrious predecessors Henri Jeanson and Jacques Prevert, Audiard mixed classic French and slang and delighted in derision and ‘bons mots’, though his dialogue was coarser (a sign of the times) and more schocking. (…) Audiard’s witty, hard-hitting dialogue underpins much of the best popular French cinema from the late 1950s to the mid-1980s, notably his collaborations with Jean Gabin, for whom he wrote tailor-made dialogue.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. The companion to French cinema. BFI Publishing, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Jacques Juranville ; director, Henri Verneuil ; writers, Albert Simonin, Michel Audiard ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Michel Magne.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Alain Delon, Maurice Biraud, Viviane Romance, Henri Virlojeux, Germaine Montero, Jean Carmet, Dora Doll.
